Please note this review assumes that you have finished watching In another World With My Smartphone and while care has been taken to minimize story spoilers there may be spoilers in character analysis. 
What happens when you die from an accident caused by god and choose to be resurrected in a fantasy world where monsters and magic exists with nothing but the clothes on your back, a magic enhanced smartphone and the ability to wield any magic in the new world. 
Based on a popular light novel series of the same name In Another World with My Smartphone is a fantasy/adventure harem anime that alsoincorporates elements of comedy into it. It’s been quite a well since I actually seen a harem anime such as this but I guess nothing much has changed. As premises go In Another World With My Smartphone makes use of one that’s been tried and tested in countless anime before in other more well-known anime such as the vaunted Konosuba series. What sets this anime apart from what can be seen in other anime’s however is not the base concept of being resurrected in an entirely new world after perishing In the original but rather the smartphone that the main character Touya has that acts as the series main plot element. 


The overall story for In another World With My Smartphone follows the life of Touya Mochizuki a 15-year-old teenager from Japan in the modern era that was killed in a freak accident by god and was given the choice to come back to life in a world of his choosing along with a wish that God would grant him. This wish and the implications of it to this new world is the centerpiece of the story and is the magic enhanced smartphone of Touya’s. After resurrection Touya finds himself in a brand-new world where both magic and monsters exist and where he finds that sometimes common sense and diplomacy are worth more than having the biggest blade or the most durable of armor. In terms of setting the overall story for In Another World with My Smartphone takes place 


Touya  


Touya voiced by new voice actor Katsumi Fukuhara with his first role is one of the main characters of the series and the main protagonist of the series. A 15-year-old teenager that was reincarnated in this world as part of the wishes that he had wanted god to grant Touya is someone that can be best described as your average Japanese teenager that’s rather unremarkable both in terms of appearance, mannerisms or ambition. Indeed, Touya can be best described as someone that’s just a normal guy that you can find anywhere in the world. The so-called everyman will be the best description for him. if he wasn’t reincarnated in the fantasy world I would say that his life would have been rather unremarkable. A calm, brave and responsible person by nature Touya is someone that is quiet and prefers not to get involved with things that concern him. This contrasts however with Touya’s strong sense of justice that manifests when he see’s innocent people getting hurt which often prompts him to get involved without thinking it through. In the beginning of the series Touya was someone that despite being sent to an entirely new world was able to remain calm and composed while determining his first steps that will ensure that he has a good foundation to start with. These base traits of his largely remain unchanged as the series go on ensuring that he remains firmly anchored and calm as he encounters people and situations that will faze even the most veteran of adventurers. 


As the series goes on Touya’s personality gradually changes as he meets more people and encounter different situations in his travels. Though Touya was far from a horrible person in the beginning as the series progresses Touya becomes more humble and kind as the series progresses even when at times he was well within his rights to request a reward for his service. In fact, Touya’s humble nature and the fact that he has little ego getting in his way can be said to be one of his most prominent traits and something that I admire about him. As can be expected of someone that was just sent to an entirely new world Touya is someone that gets curious quite easily and is always willing to learn new things. Here another prominent traits of Touya can be said to be of great use here which is his intelligence. Despite the fact that this is probably the first time that he encountered magic Touya in the series is noted to have an innate understanding of a wide array of subjects including magic, military tactics, firearms and ancient Japanese culture knowledge that he is shown to use throughout the series to deal with the unique situations that pop up. This wide array of knowledge combined with his ability to easily understand how something works can be said to be his second most prominent trait after his skill at magic. Arguably Touya’s most prominent trait that makes him such an interesting character and such a powerhouse for the team is his ability at magic. While in the beginning of the series Touya proved to be proficient with the sword which when combined with his perception skills made him a capable opponent in melee combat it is in the realm of magic that Touya can be said to truly excel at. While most mages in fantasy settings would only be able to make use of a certain number of elements Touya is able to make use of a great number of magic spells from each of the main magic elements that serve to make Touya a very capable force multiplier when fighting on the field as he is essentially someone that can use every magic element. Naturally the major plot device that can be attributed to Touya is his smartphone which unlike a normal one actually runs on magic which in this new world is more or less plentiful. The smartphone like Touya gradually improves as he gains more abilities and powers as the series progresses becoming a very capable tool in its right.  As a character, I felt that Touya was a one that though well-designed was not one that developed much in terms of personality when compared to the other characters like the girls for example. Though the character itself was not well developed I do feel that his voice actor did a good enough job in portraying him. 


Elze


Elze voiced by veteran seiyuu singer Maaya Uchida of Charlotte and Musaigen No Phantom fame is one of the main characters of the series and one of Touya’s main allies within the series. A teenage girl that acts more like a tomboy than anything else Elze is the older sister of Linze. A brave, responsible and headstrong person Elze from initial appearances may look like a normal girl from a mere glance but that’s before you actually see the over sized gauntlet that she uses as her main weapon. Personality wise Elze is someone that’s very direct whether with their words in conversation or in combat she’s the type of person that would prefer to the heart of a problem without becoming mired in pointless maneuvering in conversations.  Indeed, Elze is someone that’s more accustomed to action rather than in diplomacy than anything which contrasts well with her younger sister. True to her personality Elze is someone that possesses a lot of self-confidence that allows her to stay motivated even when she’s facing one of the most dangerous foes in the land and is someone that can be counted upon to hold the line on the field quite readily especially when combined with her skill at close combat and fortification magic.


 In the beginning of the series Elze was someone that was hard to get to know as she was slow to trust people and indeed often didn’t listen to what others had to say before proceeding onwards. This is a result of the long travels that she and her sister has been through and is a direct result of the experiences that they had from relying upon one another. However once Elze trusts someone impeccably she is shown to be more attentive to them and values the advice and words that they may have. Though slow to trust Elze is shown to be quite capable of making friends with people that can brush aside her brash personality and in this we can see that Elze can be very loyal to her friends and willing to help them the best that she can if it lies within her power. Despite Elze’s steely nature it was rather surprising to see that she can actually get embarrassed quite easily a trait that I find is quite refreshing for her. As the series progresses Elze’s personality gradually changes as she meets new allies and encounters situations that so far has been unknown to her. While in the past Elze may charge headlong into situations without a second thought confidant that her skills in close combat will be able to get her and her sister through it this aspect of her personality began to change as she learned to show more restraint in her actions and begins to think more on the actions that she can take before taking them. Initially Elze was someone that can be considered to be very up front with their feelings that comes from her straightforward nature and personality but as the series progresses this aspect evolves and Elze while still passionate with her feelings also becomes more considerate for the feelings for others. As a character, I felt that Elze was a well-designed character that while brash and hard to control at first was someone that learned that perhaps restraint and caution is better than action and might have been the better choice. I felt that her seiyuu Maaya Uchida really did an excellent job in portraying the character of Elze. 


Linze 


Linze voiced by new seiyuu Yui Fukuo in her first main role to date is one of the main characters of the series and is one of Touya’s main allies in the series. The younger sister of Elze Linze is the polar opposite to Elze in terms of both personality and behaviour. A young teenage girl and the younger of the Silhoueska twins Linze is a quiet, composed and intelligent young girl that exudes the image of an academic or maybe a veteran mage. Unlike her older sister Linze is someone that’s very cautious and diplomatic and prefers conversation rather than action. Of all of the girls Linze can be seen to be the most intelligent of the girls as in addition to being well read and learned Linze has shown to be able to use this knowledge effectively on the field to help her allies. In terms of contrast Linze I felt served as a great contrast to both her sister Elze and the rest of the cast where her cautiousness and calmness served as a great asset to the team.  This contrast of Linze’s is not just restricted to a personality level but also reflected in the battle talent that she has. Unlike her sister who’s more accustomed to fighting at the forefront of the battle due to her skill at both close combat and at fortification magic Linze serves as a mage and is shown to be especially proficient in water magic and in its sub field of ice magic in particular.  Being able to stay rational and composed while also offering effective fire support while in battle is a skill that I thought was really appropriate for Linze. An aspect of Linze’s that’s only shown in battle that I find quite amusing is Linze’s tendency to go overboard with her magic which given her personality is something that I did not expect from her. 


As the series progresses Linze’s personality gradually changes as she meets new characters and makes new friends while also exploring new lands. In the beginning of the series Linze was someone that as a result of her quiet personality was someone that got nervous rather easily and in the beginning often had great trouble in not just conversing with people but also finding the right words to use. As a result of not just meeting Touya but also the rest of the cast Linze gradually becomes more confident in herself and able to make clear to others what her thoughts and opinions on matters are far more easily than what she was like before. Seeing the quiet and meek Linze that we saw in the beginning of the series evolve into someone that was not afraid of making their voices and opinions known to others was a change that I thought was well done. While becoming more confidant in herself Linze is also noted to have become more brave and willing to stand in battle to help her friends and allies when they are in danger and in doing so showing the steely determination that was the best result of her evolution as a character. Another aspect that is unique to Linze is the fact that even though Linze is at heart someone that is well mannered, kind and composed she’s also someone that can get angry especially when someone irks her a lot. In this we can see that when she’s angry Linze’s personality markedly changes as she becomes forceful and stern and exudes a pretty menacing aura as well. As a character, I felt that Linze was an interesting character that served as a great contrast with her sister Elze and brought to the cast not just strong magical abilities but also a degree of intelligence and analytic capability that served well to help the team in their travels. I felt that her seiyuu Yui Fukuo really did a great job in her portrayal of Linze and despite this being her first main role to date I felt that she did an excellent job. 


Yumina 


Yumina voiced by new seiyuu Marika Kouno in one of her first main roles to me is one of the main characters of the show and is one of Touya’s main allies in the series. The princess of Belfast and sole daughter of the king Yumina is a kind, caring and considerate person that as expected of a princess is also very well-mannered and diplomatic. Though within the series Yumina is but a 12-year-old girl Yumina is shown to take her duties as a princess quite seriously and is very loyal to both her parents and to the country as well and as a result is willing to take part in state visits to other countries to negotiate with the people there. Unlike the other girls in the show whose special skills come from years of practice Yumina’s special skill which allows her to see the true personality of someone is something that she was born with which gave her a rather interesting ability that has proved useful to both her and to her parents and the country. 


In the beginning of the series Yumina was seen to be someone that didn’t trust easily and though friendly on the surface was also shown to be wary of people that she didn’t know. Both of these traits are a by-product of being a nations princess as she in this role is expected to meet a great many different people not all of which are trueful. However, as the series progresses Yumina though never completely letting down her guard gradually becomes more positive, considerate and more expressive with her true feelings which I felt was something that she needed since the heavy responsibility of being a princess I think is not something that a 12-year-old girl should have to shoulder. One aspect of her character that I found to be interesting was the fact that Yumina is actually a very capable combatant being a very capable mage and archer despite her young age. In this she differed from more traditional princess like characters that had to rely on guards to protect them. This I felt was a welcome change to her. Overall as a character I felt Yumina was interesting as despite being a princess she had none of the negative traits that they usually had and treated everyone with respect and kindness something most nobles would struggle with. I felt that her seiyuu Marika Kouno really did a great job in voicing her. 


Yae 


Yae voiced by veteran seiyuu Chinatsu Akasaki of Food Wars and Trinity Seven fame is one of the main characters of the series and one of Touya’s main allies in the series. A female swordswoman from the far away land of Eashen that Touya and the gang encounter during their time in Belfast Yae is someone that can be best described as what a typical samurai if they were sent into the fantasy world would be like. A honorable and kind-hearted person by nature Yae despite her young age is someone that has trained extensively with the sword and is a very accomplished swordswoman in her own right despite her age. Despite her young age Yae had elected to travel the world in order to both explore and learn new techniques that she can incorporate into her own showing that she is also someone that’s not just brave but also a bit of a free spirit as well. Personality wise Yae has a number of prominent personality traits that serve to define her. The central motivation that Yae makes use of in the story is without a doubt her firm sense of justice which stems from not just her status as a warrior but also from her own personal beliefs that state that evil should be punished at every turn. This means that when encountering quests that call for the elimination or disabling of enemies judged to be evil Yae will often get motivated enough to fight them. Despite being a powerful combatant in close combat Yae is shown to be amusingly clumsy at times which I felt was quite amusing and helps offset the fact that she’s that powerful. The last prominent trait of Yae is her manner of speech and her accent which I find to be pretty funny. As a character, I felt that Yae was a well-designed character that showed that even if you are from a far-off land the sense of justice and morals can surprisingly be the same as well. Chinatsu Akasaki, I felt did an excellent job in portraying the character of Yae despite her lack of development when compared to the other girls.  


Arts and animation 


Overall, I felt that the arts and animation for the series was relative good with both the environmental settings and the scenery being pretty well made. The character designs for each of the main characters I felt were nice and each character’s outfit was unique, well designed and well thought out. The combat animations though decent I felt was one thing that could be improved on. The effects of magic that were released by mages like Linze and Yumina I felt were pretty impressive. 


Music 


The opening theme for the series which was Another World by AOP I felt was pretty catchy and did a great job of setting the mode for the series. The series though only having one ending theme is notable for having each of the main heroines sing it for one or two episodes which was interesting. The ending theme for the series was Junjou Emotional which was also a catchy song that sounded quite relaxing and pleasant to listen to. 


Voice acting 


Voice acting for the series was solid and I felt that praise should go to Maaya Uchida who voiced Elze, Yui Fukuo who voiced Linze, Marika Kouno who voiced Yumina and Chinatsu Akasaki who voiced Yae who I felt all did an excellent job at voicing their characters. 


Overall conclusion 


In Overall In Another World with my Smartphone was an interesting anime whose strong points was its interesting premise, interesting story and well-designed characters. The comedic side of the show was also something that I thought was well done. The overall premise that the show makes use of namely being transported to a different world after death is not one that is rare within the industry and rather is one of the most common scenarios that originated from the renowned Re Zero series. Here though the one thing that managed to create some semblance of change to the premise was the shows ultimate plot device the smartphone. Bringing in equipment from other worlds and into a world where technology is lower is a common enough theme but here the series also introduces items that serve to improve the world such as ice cream, bicycles, shogi boards and firearms. This change was something that I welcomed as it made the story that much more interesting. Since the smartphone evolved in parallel with Touya’s abilities in my view it become more than just a tool but rather it become both a weapon and a tome of knowledge for him.  


However, despite the interesting premise and the capable voice cast I felt that the series had a lot of things that it could have improved on to make it that more interesting. Character development in the series I felt was rather inconsistent with the main character of Touya largely staying as he was at the start while characters like Linze and Elze get decent development while the other girls did not. The combat scenes in the series I felt were overly simple despite the care taken in designing the fights themselves. A problem that the show inherits from its source material is that the main characters with one notable exception never actually faces any real threat to their lives that they had to overcome by putting their minds and powers to novel uses. If the main characters are challenged more in their battles then I think a combination of Touya’s intellect and the girl’s various abilities would have been better used. Overall as a final score I would give In another World with my Smartphone a final score of 6/10. While the premise and story were good and the main characters were well designed the lack of effective character development  made it too genetic in my eyes.

I believe almost everyone who starts watching this anime would think the same thing as me, "Is this Konosuba rip-off? MC dies and 'god' revived him to another world. This is exactly same as Konosuba!".
Well, that's what I thought at first, but I won't go by that wild mind for the rest of the season, so I accept the fact that there are a lot of Isekai theme out there and the plot could be similar to one another. Case closed with "Konosuba rip-off" everyone talking about.
(updated my review for the last episode)
Story: 5
First of all, this anime is more like a Slice of Lifestory rather than an Adventure and while I said that this anime is not a rip-off of Konosuba, I won't lie to myself that I didn't get the enjoyment like I got from Konosuba, both anime have the same plot as MC dies and revived but the BIG difference from both anime is the whole character themselves.

I won't talk much about Konosuba as you already know that anime well.


Let's start talking about the MC, he is OP AS F***. 'god' gave him a buff as a compensation from his blunder ('god' accidentally dropped some lightning on the world and it hits the MC ).

Instead of giving the MC a slight buff to make him capable of casting magic, this 'god' make the MC like a freakin' god himself.


Basically the MC got massive buff as he could cast all the elements and could copy others "null" magic. (watch the 1st episode and you'll understand this null thing).

I watched 'til episode 9 and there is no such thing as "the MC got wrecked or the MC having a hard time to deal with his New World".

I heard that in the Light Novel the story also goes like this and the MC still never having a hard time to everything. Welp.


And for the girls, all the girl are cute and strong enough to defend themselves from monster's attacks. Done.

Yes, that's the only worth telling. lel

Seems like there is nothing "good point" from this review but that's what it is.

Despite from that, I still recommend this anime if you like generic plot anime with magic and OP MC.

I almost lost all my respect for Touya when he said that he will marry all those 4 so lightly. If only Touya originally is from this Isekai in the first place maybe I won't be thinking this way, because the difference of culture with our REAL world. 

In our world you can't just marry 4 or even 9, yeah, NINE girls at the same time.


Some people find it (last episode) fun to watch because not many harem anime would actually have this kind of route. But some poeple (including me) would get irritated by Touya's decision.


I don't want to take this anime seriously -especially the ending- because this is just parody but unfortunately I can't.

This anime would be a great way to explain one of Descartes' theory of existentialism. Touya dies in his "real world" but wasn't supposed to die so his God (a supreme being is a confirmed in this anime) apologizes by putting him in another world where magic exists and the industrial revolution never happened. Here's where it gets interesting, it wouldn't be far from the realm of reality to assume that Touya was never actually placed in a second external world by God but that he was deceived by God to think that he was in a real genuine second world where magic exists. Away to affirm this is how God made him the most powerful entity (aside from himself) in this world and told Touya to live a little when confronted with the moral dilemma of marrying a 14 year old (Touya is 16). This means (just a theory) that there is no real external world where magic exists that Touya is currently in but this is just a dream state that God put Touya in when he died and went to heaven. It can be summarized and assumed that the world Touya is currently in was made for him to live out his wildest fantasies. The only thing that technically can be proved is ones own existence, so there is no proof that can be offered that Touya is in a genuine external world instead of a dream like world. "Cogito ergo sum." - Descartes

The problem with this series is that it is a Titanic. It had an idea that, for an anime, could have turned into something truly epic for a fantasy story but instead it took its plot and crashed it straight into an iceberg.
The main character isn't drawn too well and his character is blander than vanilla ice-cream. He is made pointlessly OP and the main drawing point of the anime, the smartphone, is almost never used.
Instead it is merely mentioned or pulled out once or twice an episode to ensure we never forget it.
The other characters are all such stereotypes that it only serves tograte on the nerves every time one of them speaks. \n\n
This anime is only good in that it is so bad it might make you laugh and guffaw at its mediocrity and regurgitation of other, far more superior anime with similar themes. \n\n
My advice then is to watch it only if you are a zealot for fantasy anime of any kind or if you want to laugh at a bad anime with some friends.

Honestly, this is a show that can't be reviewed with a mere number. Once in a while, a special kind of series comes along, one that looks like the anime equivalent of a movie you'd see on MST3K.
It's not really about the personality-less girls, nor is it about how tropey this show gets. 
For me, as with many from what I'm seeing, the entirety of this show comes down to it's incredibly overpowered protagonist. 
Which brings us to Touya, our main character... or as I like to call him 'jesus'. And I think that episode 9 has a line that sums up whats so bad..yet surprisingly endearing about this anime.\n
"It's not even surprising at this point."\n
This is the problem with Jesus-kun, by the third episode, the viewer has become used to the idea that the hero wins by pulling some kind of spell out of his ass mere minutes after the problem/villain appears.\n
Even in most 'battle harem' anime, the protagonist, while designed to be 'relate-able' so to speak, always has his own obstacles to face and more often than not the majority of villains are stronger than him when they first appear.\n
We're all used to the concept of characters 'breaking their limits', but the MC has no limits to begin with, and thats... abundantly clear..\n
In addition, the rest of the cast is composed of incredibly bland and predictable archetypes that you could basically make a drinking game out of the constant tropes in the show\n
Yet surprisingly, all this is exactly what makes this anime so goddamn great, while not exactly self aware, it doesn't even bother to hide any of this. The typical episode goes as follows\n
1. Problem\n
2. Everyone panicking and terrified\n
3. MC non-chalant about it\n
4. MC nonchalantly solves problem\n\n
It gets to the point where the other members of the cast actually acknowledge how powerful he is, but while the show seems self aware, it doesn't give us enough comedic moments to pass off as something like Konosuba.\n
Instead it passes off as what it is, a show that is self aware about it's blandness and lack of stakes and originality\n
And whenever the show does something, it almost becomes a game among viewers in the room to name what anime they had already seen that done better in.\n
In the long run, if you want an anime that you wanna riff on with your friends.... this is that anime for the season\n
.

Story:
While the story in the anime is turning out to be complete trash, the standards it uses coupled with it's intended demographic and genre make it appropriate for what it is. The only thing stopping me from dropping the score down to a 2 is the fact that it was never meant to be an action-packed show.
Art:
If this anime came out in 2010, I would rate this no less than an 8. However, so many anime came out with the same art direction since then, that this one does not do anything new and innovative, actually looking a bit bland on the color department. Buthey, I've seen much worse; however, I've seen much better as well.


Sound:


While I'm only on episode 4, the soundtrack so far does not do anything memorable or sticks to me anyway at all. Both the opening and the ending don't really symbolize much at this point and the songs are kind of lame and unmemorable. It certainly doesn't offend me, nor does it make me want to jump out my bedroom window, but again, I've heard much worse and better.



Character:


Character by far is the worst part of this show. None of the characters receive any proper development or backstory nor go through any personal struggle. This is mainly because of the MC, your run of the mill overpowered god (I understand the reference) that automatically possesses the power to negate any personal strife that they need to overcome, a pivotal point for the progression of the story and any of the attachment that the viewer might have to the characters. This is not pathetic, because the intended genre is specialized for these types of MC's.


Enjoyment:


Coming from a 15 year old, seeing a boy of similar age with jaw dropping girls drooling all over him certainly does not offend me. However, I'm no pervert either. This does get old as you move to episode 4, and I can't imagine anything refreshing about it either; however, something about this anime, whether it be the humanized MC or my raging hormones prevents me from rating this any lower than a six. However, they stop there as logic takes over, preventing me from rating this any higher either.


Overall:


Overall, if you like female harems and women who would instantly get on their knees for a man, want to see the MC succeed in every task and blow everyone away like he's God, then this is the anime for you. However, those of you searching for anything else should look elsewhere, because this probably would disappoint.

If you are looking for an OP MC and an MC with a harem, this is it.
This anime seems a bit rush due to the fact that there is little character development.
Also, I feel like the MC should have some sort of "grind". By grind I mean, he actually has to work for his powers. It looks like "god" just made him OP and probably the strongest dude out there.
I'm not really into the harem vibe I am getting. It looks like he is getting a new girl every episode there is.
Overall this anime is enjoyable to watch for me. I like OP MC's.

How can you describe this anime; Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni.? It's pretty easy. Just say out loud the official English title of this anime; In Another World With My Smartphone.
In Another World With My Smartphone is about Mochizuki, a young teenage boy who was accidentally killed. To apologise to Mochizuki, God allows him to ask of any one thing to be brought with him to be summoned to another fantasy world to which Mochizuki asks for merely a smartphone to be brought to this fantasy world. Being an anime that is set in a fantasy world where the protagonist is being summoned intoafter their death on Earth, this is seen as a cliche and is compared greatly to Konosuba. Being summoned by God himself, he is given an over substantial amount of magic power to which he is "OP" and able to conquer anything in this fantasy world. This is what sets this anime apart from Konosuba, and is also what makes it comparably worse. 


To distract us from his over powered buffs he gets from God and immense invincibility, this anime makes sure to set up a harem-like setting where he forms a group with some girls with him being the only male and leader of the group. Again, this is another similarity to Konosuba and this anime can be called a clone of Konosuba; a much worse one in fact.


As Mochizuki is over powered, we know that any complication in the plot and any "suspensful" moment becomes meaningless as we already know that there will be a simple resolution as he can just say the "magic word" and he saves the day and ends the episode to this pointless Konosuba copycat of an anime.


The OST to this anime is not that good. The music get's too dramatic and distracting, especially when it comes between the dialogue and interactions between characters. The soundtrack is usually meant to fill the blank space to not make the dialogue so bland, but the soundtrack merely just overpowers the dialogue and distracts us from the plot and what is going on. On the contrary, the voice acting for the characters are good. There's nothing really bad I can say or criticise about the voice acting. The seiyuus are all good.


Character development is done well in this anime. Since there is no deep complications that happen in this anime, development of characters are done easily with no need of dramatisation and development is also complemented by the harem-setting of this anime.


The character designs are very familiar and pretty average. There is nothing unique and the characters all look like either your sterotypical male protagonist in a fantasy world or the accompanying female moe cast who are in this endless harem on this one male protagonist. There is also nothing really special about the animation style. It's pretty average.


All in all, this is a pretty average show that is probably not worth your time if you were looking for something different or substantial. But, if you wanted to see something fast-pace that gets straight to the point regardless if there is no suspense or barriers for the main cast, then I recommend that you watch this anime.


In Another World With My Smartphone. The title sums up the plot of the anime. If that's what you're looking for, then that's what you're getting.

This is why no-one respects anime.
The initial premise (young man reincarnated in a magical world - but he takes along his smartphone) sounded stupid, yet potentially fun in a daft way.
Of course, then a decision was made that rather than being a fish out of water but with a bizarre advantage, he should actually be amazing at everything. Like, the best character in the entire world at every single thing he tries his hand at.
Fine, I've seen this Gary Stu nonsense before - it's poor writing wish fulfilment nonsense, but it is what it is.
Except then it turns out to actually be some harem animenonsense - the protaganist is swarmed by perpetually flustered hordes of essentially breasts with sketched in personalities appended. Sure, it's an unhealthy attitude to women viewing them as essentially props for the audience and main character to lust over (while of course the writers make him feign innocence). It even acknowledges this - ironic lampshading being the main form of humour in the show.\n\n
But the bit which is particularly objectionable is that the creators have included literal children as love interests. This has gone from "pathetic wish fulfilment" to "pathetic wish fulfilment for the sort of people who assure you that 'she's very mature for a 12 year old'".\n\n
This is symptomatic of a problem across anime, which justifiably gets it looked down upon by the majority of people who are aware of this aspect, but yet for some reason it is still not only accepted as a subculture, but shows like this specifically design characters around having children for that part of the audience to lust over.\n\n
And no, the main character saying he'll wait until she is 14 before he marries her is not an acceptable way to get around this problem.\n\n
Y'all should be ashamed of yourselves.

At first I had my doubts, my first thoughts were oh this is just your average isekai, with the obvious character tropes they always have, and while that might be true, it's still entertaining to watch. Unlike most isekai, this show doesn't have much in terms of tension or drama, because in every situation where something could happen, the mc, Touya, always has the spell to solve the issue. And because he can do this, after every girl he saves from some kind of situation, they inevitably fall for him and join his group.
I want to get the record and say that this show isin no way comparable in terms of quality to the greats such as FMAB, Steins;Gate and all but it has a special charm to it. The show excels on what it intended to do, i.e. entertainment, humor, and sending a message.


The cons:

- Mediocre art and animation

- Unoriginal character personality types

- Bad character designs

- Not much character development

- OP MC

- Problems are solved too quickly


Now, the Pros:


The show went all out unlike most serious in this genre, the MC is right in the middle from most male mc's in isekai harems, he isn't a super shy, weak, bashful guy, but he also isn't a super perverted, strong but dumb hero, and his goal isn't to get all the girls. Instead he is a smart, strong, morally correct, confident hero, who isn't completely dense. He makes sure to bring up his morals in almost any instance where it is important, including the last episode which was very satisfying compared to most harem anime.


Final Thoughts:


The soundtracks only purpose is to fit the mood of each scene which does well at doing that but nothing more. The story isn't anything special, just your average isekai, harem just without the usual drama.


If you're going into this show expecting a masterpiece, well don't unless you find harem anime extremely good, but for anyone else, you should expect an entertaining harem/comedy with a satisfying ending.


What was enjoyable about the series was that it had it's funny moments where isekai usually fail to hit, as well as where harem anime also fails to hit. By all means this isn't an anime for story driven viewers but more for a person who enjoys isekai or a person of comedy.


Verdict:


Story: 6

Enjoyment: 10

Overall: 9

Probably the most boring main protagonist i've ever seen in an anime. The girl with the Japanese themed clothes has an obnoxious habit of saying gozaru on her last sentences every single time, which is really annoying. The fight scene are bland and generic, didn't really like the art either. The story is just as boring as the main protagonist, some scenes just doesn't make any sense like for example in the first episode in the alley, why would the twin sisters go to a dark alley just to do a simple item transaction, are they selling crack too as a side job? Because that'swhere a crack dealer would probably sell their stuff.

There's a certain art to writing an OP MC. When done well it makes for a very enjoyable show. Prime examples of this include the expertly written Saitama and Mob from genius writer ONE. So why is it that this show fails so spectacularly in writing an OP MC and as a show in general? Let's break it down.
Characters are only made interesting by their flaws or their challenges. Saitama faces existential dread wondering what his purpose in life is after achieving the overwhelming strength he desired. This challenge of finding fulfillment in life is universal of the human experience and achieves the incredible featof making a person with godlike strength feel human and relatable. Mob is a kid going through puberty and trying to deal with all of these new emotions he's experiencing while also possessing godlike powers that are directly influenced by his emotions. Once again this makes him feel relatable as we all went through this and felt new emotions that made us confused. The reason I bring these two good OP MCs up is to help convey how poorly written Touya and by extension this show is.


Touya faces no real challenges or flaws in his character. He's killed at 15 due to a mistake from God. Now you'd think this would cause some conflict or some trials. But nope! He takes it perfectly in stride and God decides to buff him as his way of saying sorry. He has superhuman speed and durability and can use every magic element in his new world. He heals the blind and poisoned, saves the king, helps random children who are lost, and is successful at every single thing he does. That is the main issue with this show. Touya is a pure Gary Sue in every sense of the word. There's no personal conflict with him. No trials or tribulations or failure. Touya therefore comes across as an incredibly boring character who feels completely unrelatable.


The rest of the show is very paint by numbers. The art is fine. The sound is fine. Really the rest of it is just fine. If you can look past the complete failure of character writing this show has then it's a perfect little time killer. But if you want a good OP MC show check out ONE's shows. They're funny, action packed, and most importantly well written.

A generic Isekai anime with an overpowered as fuck main character, that doesn't truly bring anything unique or refreshing to the table. The characters are all flat, clones of something you've definitely seen before somewhere else. The plot doesn't really seem to go anywhere, and there is an inherent lack of a main antagonist anywhere. There are some humorous moments strewn throughout the show, and i must admit that i managed to scrounge some enjoyment out of powering through the 12 episodes at once. The biggest issue that I faced with the show was that almost nothing gets accomplished by the end of the show.A good time waster, if nothing else.  6.5 out of 10.

First things first. My "reviews" system is explained on a blog entry. Which can be found through my profile.
------
Slogan of this anime in a nutshell. "It was oddly so generic that it made it good."
------
✦Story
This whole Anime or story itself or the whole setting felt really odd. To sum it up it felt as seeing some seasoned developer becoming some sort of gamemaster (GM) of some sort of a RPGmaker generic game, but playing the game in debug mode plus using development skills to implement some new things into game however that developer wants to.
Hard to explain, but everything that happens in this Anime isoddly plain and generic, but it feels so generic, that is somehow makes it good.


And seeing our MC to adventure in such a world was comical and oddly satisfying. Every story element and every thing thing that got introduced in that world felt like something out of old typical RPGmaker game. We get overpowered character in a comical and odd manner, world has essentially most basic and plain stock spells, where our MC can learn all "free of charge".


But how the story was presented and built, even know actively knowing that it was quite "generic", it was simply superb. I generally don't dislike "generic" as I translate it as "traditional". But the idea how such a troupe was used and handled felt as parody itself.


Another great element is having funny modern device that is oddly very useful and powerful in the fantasy world. It had a lot of oddity and questionably about quite some story elements and characters considering how our MC brought shift in power balance and "tech".


✦Art & Sound

"Stock assets of RPGmaker."

Jokes aside, art felt very underwhelming, but I did like the character designs and some of the magic. Oh... and I really didn't like most of the swimsuits there...

Music did actually have some presence. Did enjoy quite a few tracks.


✦Character

"Stock filler NPCs and a bit better built party member NPCs".

Once again, jokes aside, I found that the stereotypes were used quite nicely and in a entertaining way. Our main character was a bit less standard than most isekai series. He was less standard and maybe I even I didn't really like him as much, but how he was set-up in that world and how all of it went along, somehow made it comical thus I can accept him as character.


Also we have a superb harem of all sorts of girls. Some I liked, some not. But the best part about this harem is. Would be that it actually is successful harem and can and probably will be legitimate harem in that world.


Generic and stereotypical characters that were shown in a very enjoyable way. As I have said in the past. " "Generic" and "stereotypes" are superb if they are done and used right."


✦Enjoyment & Overall

It was all around odd Anime, but how everything was put together and used. Felt as whole satisfying, straightforward, chill and fun. In another words it felt good, thus it gets 7 from me.

Story: What story? THERE IS NO STORY. Most of the time the main character just randomly stumbles upon problems or takes jobs and...that's it. 
Art: The character designs are pretty bad. The fight scenes are quite poorly done and well everything...doesn't look great. 
Sound: I'm not really good at grading sound but it just sounds quite bland and boring. 
Character: As far as I can tell, they don't have any character. Touya is the most generic and nice character I've ever seen. He's just nice and helpful and can do anything and everyone is constantly in awe at his amazing powers?? like every episode youjust realise "oh without him doing anything he can actually use this random other super rare ability with little effort". He doesn't have any motivation or...anything really in him? And the rest of the cast is just as generic and convenient and show up when they need to show up. \n\n
Enjoyment: I was really. really. bored. It just kept dragging on listening to magic explanations, watching Touya be able to cast the spell without problems, watching Touya save somebody else again, watching him become friends with everyone. \n\n
Well if you enjoy it, then that's great for you! But if you're like me and find every moment completely pointless since nobody seems to have any motivation or personality in this series, uhh don't watch it.

It's another "Isekai" anime, but I really like the characters. Enough that I went and bought every light novel that has been translated to English and have number 10 on pre-order through Amazon.
Part of the reason I like it so much is the light novels, they have gone so far beyond the the final episode that there's enough material for 3 or 4 more seasons, which I would happily watch. There are some minor differences, but overall, the anime is faithful to the light novels, the script must have been written by a fan.
The final episodes is loaded for bear with hints of what's tocome, the introduction of Ende, the number and identities of Touya's brides-to-be through end credit artwork(although I'm guessing at the final bride's identity, she has not been revealed as such in volume 9) The initial 4 plus two(Introduced, but they aren't revealed as brides in the first season) are the only ones you'll meet in the anime.\n\n
This was not a series I had great hopes for initially, the title almost kept me from watching it. Is it great art or a masterpiece? I can't claim that, but I will say it is great fun, worth multiple rewatches and the novels rereading for favorite parts. Not an especially heavy read or watch, but just plain fun.

What stood out to me in this anime, above all else, was the MC. Touya is probably the closest to Mr. Perfect I've encountered thus far. Aside from being oblivious to the romantic intentions of his companions, he's smart enough to find solutions to problems relatively painlessly. He's overpowered, but only uses as much as he needs to for any given situation and isn't overly flashy. He's humble, but not shy. He's very kind, but doesn't put himself down for the sake of others. The only thing I could dislike about him is that he's too perfect. Subaru is my favorite male MC for thesame reasons he's so hated by most fans - he's heavily flawed. I can relate to him because of that. Touya is just so perfect that he never needs my sympathy and he never makes me reflect on myself. 


As for the supporting characters, I wasn't enthralled by any of them, but I couldn't find anything wrong with them either. The only change I would make would be introducing Francesca much earlier on, because I think her personality is a foil to the others that adds a lot of depth. 


The story was pretty average in general, but the pacing was good. There wasn't a gripping storyline that I wanted to see to the end; instead, there was a series of minor arcs that were all interesting enough to make me want to keep watching, without any stretches of boring nothing in between.


I don't have anything interesting to report for the art and sound. They're both pretty average. Taken together with everything else, this anime is a solid 7 for me. I guess for most people that's not very high, but I standardize my ratings so 7 is very good.

I really liked this anime. I had started watching it a while back and I was liking it but for some reason I had dropped it back then. I came back to it now and I loved it. I binge watched it and it's been a while since an anime has gotten me to do that.         The story doesn't really have a goal but that's not the point. The point is to just enjoy a show about a fantasy world with cute anime girls, while the MC is so OP and can do anything he wants todo.  You can imagine yourself as him. This show is supposed to be a feel good show. You get to put yourself in the MC's shoes and the MC is overpowered and has it all. He get's so much social gratication wherever he goes. The social gratification is one of the main parts that this shows uses a lot. This show gives you a lot of social gratification since it gives the MC a lot of social gratification. It really is just a nice simple adventure fantasy anime. All that stuff about having an end goal isn't always necessary, since it puts a strain on anything else other than that. The art is good but the animation and fight scenes sometimes look a bit rough but its not a big deal at all. Easily ignorable. In this show lots of good stuff keeps on happening and its just a really posative and happy anime and I really enjoyed it. Sometimes its good to just have a laid back anime thats always posative.                   BIG SPOILER TO THE ANIME AHEAD:

Is this anime absurdly awful to levels incomprehensible to the human race? Yes.
Did I enjoy this anime despite it's massive flaws? Yes.
Smartphone Isekai Anime is fucking awful. Like, holy shit, it's so garbage it blows my mind.
Now, you may ask yourself, if it's as bad as I claim it is why did I say I enjoyed it? Because I liked how relaxed and stupid it was. That simplicity is something I can apreciate in a show.
The writing is abhorrently bad, in sense that the show is full of clichés, extremely inconsistent within it's logic and really predictable when it comes to how things happen withinthe episodes. Thing is, it didn't bother me. Probably because I completly turned off my brain while watching it.
