Fun stuff. Hoping for a second season.

I'll try my best to be straight to the point. Before this anime came out, I honestly thought it would be roughly similar like Konosuba after reading the title and synopsis. Turns out, I've got something different from what I expected... 
Story:
You guys read the synopsis right? There you have it. The story is sooo peaceful that I felt like nothing bad happens throughout the ending. There's some intense and fighting scenes but, damn this dude's cellphone is useful and he's got a 'real life aimbot'. Oh wait, it was an offer from God, so that's why...
Art:
Not the best, but I can live with it.Drawings are fine, but the animations are quite lacking... But whatever, you get fan service anyways.


Sound:

You've got a generic high tempo pop music (battle style) OP or whatever I just don't know how to describe it. Its not bad, OK? It just fits the anime theme. ED? didn't listen.


Character:

MC - CheatEngine, aimbot, trainer, hesoyam, worshipme, helloladies 

4 girls - Loves the MC very much, generic tsundere, kawaii


Enjoyment;

This show didn't actually quite grab me (I've paused this for awhile just to watch other shows). I do enjoy some moments but not enough to keep me watching till the end.


Overall:

I think this show is suitable people who just needed some break after watching heart-breaking or intense shows. Nothing fancy, just a very peaceful OP life with girls and no sacrificing stuff.

TLC's Sister Wives was a better love story than this. Which makes me wonder if whoever wrote In Another World dabbles in a little TLC viewership. I mean, I don't really like or dislike harems, but this was just really cringey to watch. Mega crazy powerful for no reason MC gets everything handed to him for being... mega crazy powerful. Every. Episode. I have nothing notable to say about the story, characters, art work or sound that hasn't already been majorly flogged by every other reviewer.
BUT...
If you're the kind of person that just wants to sit back and watch the world burn - this isa good watch.

I'm gonna say this straight: If you treat this show seriously, it's seriously bad. There's no question about it...
but...
I'm not sure if the author wanted to make it in such a way, but it's a brilliant parody of other isekai shows! I don't really remember names of the characters, places or anything from this show, all I remember is that I was laughing so hard at the adventures of White Kirito and his harem that I couldn't breathe.
You won't find here any intriguing plot, you won't find here many interesting characters, you won't find here beautiful worlds or heartbreaking drama. But my god this isfunny as hell...\n\n
Go watch it, set your expectations to the lowest setting and just have a laugh, it's well worth it!

Oh my god! The premise is just like Konosuba, with no creativity what so ever.  Dying, being reborn and choosing whatever you want to bring. Like what!!! I can’t believe they just copied the idea like that.  From the guilds to the types of people they encounter everything is identical, although, everything was put on easy mode.
I could list so many things in common like:
Ep 2: The magic spell ‘aports’ is the same as steal. The reference to stealing pantsu was ALSO there.
Ep 3: Fighting a dullahan and Megumin’s Explosion which is now Linze’s Explosion
Ep 5: The neet in Konosuba is very comparableto the slime researcher, and Satou helping Megumin train like Touya helping Linze.

Ep 6: The wagon trip in ep 6 is also like Konosuba S2 Ep 7.


Story: 6/10

In this show, there was an overarching story about an advanced civilization but it didn’t really dive deep into it much. It was mostly small adventures where Touya just saves everyone and they all praise him.  It can get very boring at times for some, since he is pretty much an unstoppable force that just does everything perfectly.  Everything goes well and it’s very predictable.  Some parts of the comedy ran off as being very cliché although I believe that was what the writers were trying to do.  Overall, the story was very forgettable but if you enjoy seeing the main character putting everyone in awe then this will be a good watch for you.  There were so many things left as a cliffhanger to this show like the Fraze and the Partheno Civilization, which are probably the most original things that this series offered.


Art: 5/10

The art style is your typical isekai show but it is sub par compared to other shows.  Its barely polished and very flat. Especially in the insides of rooms, where you can clearly see windows with the sun shining in but no shadows casted in the room. The animation from the fight scenes were so terrible with barely any movement either.


Sound: 6/10

The opening was to my liking.  The other soundtracks were average.  It works fine with the scenes but aren’t really remarkable.  There’s nothing really wrong with any of their voices but they are very boring when put with their character types.  


Character: 5/10

None of the characters were memorable or unique but their interactions are still pretty funny.  The main character was very cookie cutter.  They all have many of the isekai tropes but they are well done.  The problem is that they are unchanging.  From the start to the finish of the show there is barely any character progression.  It seems like the only reason the harem girls were there were to show how perfect Touya was.  They are very boring characters that are the downside of this show.


Enjoyment: 8/10

These types of isekai shows are my guilty pleasure.  I just love the reactions that characters from the fantasy world have from interacting with the main character, who has tons of knowledge from our world about trivial things like making food like ice-cream or riding bicycles. It was so generic and cliché that it had me laughing.


Overall: 6.5/10

I recommend this show to people who enjoy the usual isekai shows where the mc is trapped in an RPG type world with overpowered abilities.

But if you want to see the better shows of this genre, I recommend series like Konosuba or Overlord.

So i know my rating is a bit generous, the story honestly isnt any good if you're looking for a non op protagonist, the guy doesnt even fail once, however i did enjoy this for comedy reasons, and i feel thats what this anime was aiming for, it really doesnt take itself seriously, sub par story but its enjoyable if you just want a laugh, also his use of his smart phone is actually quite creative, which is why im giving a 7 on story, it utilizes what it has and, while yeah people are stupid about their feelings, and the op is just oblivousto anything about the girls, its consistent, it doesnt try pull things out of nowhere in a tense moment, you can tell from the first episode that the mc is gonna be op\n\n
so yeah, as long as you arnt looking for a character that goes thru growth (theres actually a little here towards the end) and just want something you can laugh at, this is for you

Introduction: 
I've just finished Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni or in English, In Another World With My Smartphone. And to be honest, I was kinda disappointed. I'm a massive fan of the Isekai genre, and while this show itself isn't that bad, it definitely could've been much better. I've heard rumours for a season 2 so hopefully they can improve.
Story: 4/10
The uttermost worst part of this show had to be the story, so many different parts were just planned out horribly, I loved that they displayed the differences in culture by making the Main Character create stuff from his Original World in the worldhe's been faced with. It really shows how much cultures differentiate, I also loved the parts how they showed the economy, a lot of good other worldly anime skip the whole aspect but I love having a look at the economy such as Guilds and how much they get for their adventures.

The whole "adventure" part ends abruptly, leaving you with a ton of disappointment, it ended in about the fourth episode I'd say. Around that time you have EVERY female character falling head over heels for the single male character (there were others but an extremely insignificant amount had ANY meaning at all.)

The ONLY other reason this even gets a "poor" scoring in my eyes is the comedy. It was quite humorous at times, but, really, doesn't save it much.


Art: 9/10


The art was the saving grace for me, it looked stunning to me. Nothing much else to say.


Sound: 6/10


I liked the characters' voice acting but the Opening itself wasn't the greatest, I just ended up skipping through it most of the time and I didn't even take the time to listen to the Ending.


Character: 4/10


I've already explained the reasons for the low score when it comes to the Characters, they were just made horribly. I don't believe any thought process went into this, probably should've just made this into a Hentai instead. The characters were made extremely horribly and I was actually amazed at how fast the writers changed this from Adventure to borderline Hentai.


Enjoyment: 7/10


Outside of the reasons above, the comedy was quite fun but I wouldn't recommend it based on that alone.


Overall: 5/10


Really, a mess of a show. Started off AMAZING but it turned around extremely fast and really, it's embarrassing. I definitely will not be watching this again nor would I recommend it.

This is my first time writing an anime review but I hope you found this review helpful.
I give this anime quality rating 2/10 but the enjoyment I get out of it is a solid 8/10. 
Hear me out.
When you watch this show, you shouldn't go in with the mindset "This is a bad anime." but rather "This is gonna be so bad and I should laugh about it." because this is not a "conventional anime" but rather "So bad that it's good kind of show."
If you ever watch movie like The room,Troll 2 or Fateful Findings and you enjoy those type of movie, you goingto enjoy this anime.


This anime contains following quality:

One-dimensional and hollow characters, odd pacing, super plain soundtrack , non-funny comedy, generic art style, tons of cliché, poorly written script, generic fan service and annoying mascot.


And finally.

The story is non-sense, laughable and so predictable.

In fact , It is so predictable that I can tell what is going to happen in next 2 episodes when I'm watching it.


Despite all of that, I still enjoy watching it and laugh for how bad it is.

It's not boring at all. I can say that this is one of my favorite guilty pleasure.


I give this anime a 2/10 rating because how bad it is and I couldn't bring myself to give it better score even though I enjoy this show so much. 


Finally, I think this show teach you what a bad anime really is and it's help you appreciate good anime even more.


If you like "So bad that it's good movies" then be sure to check it out.

This anime is not great.  Although, not great it is no where near the garbage these other reviews are saying it is.  The story is unoriginal, the characters are all cliches, but the art is good and when your not looking for an original masterpiece it is very entertaining.  If your looking for something new and revolutionary, look elsewhere but if you are looking for a show to watch when you have a little downtime this is a perfect time killer. 
Story: like almost every other "isekai" show (yet this one gets bashed more harshly than other?)
Art: colorful, bright and and theanimations were not bad.


Sound: pretty normal nothing outstanding but nothing bad either.


Characters: They are all cliches but there is nothing wrong with that. They are cliches for a reason they are popular and entertaining.  The cliches were set up well enough and makes the show lighthearted.


Enjoyment: Like i said before as long as you take the show for what it is, a lighthearted, laid back comedy, you will not be mad at the series.

Normally I'd write a comprehensive review, and probably almost repeat myself a few times, but I feel like my sentiments can be summed up in one word: disappointment.
The plot had potential, and was ruined by the sudden influx of harem jealously and boobs. And the lack of plot development, beyond the very generic main story line of regular guy turns extremely OP master race  left me very deflated.
Many compare this to Konosuba, but the only factor they have in common is roughly how both main characters end up in a parallel world filled with myth and magic. Both worlds operate similarly, but that's wherethe fantasy element kicks in. The story lines have nothing in common.


While at first I did enjoy the story, line delivery, and scene transitions, the last few episodes left a less pleasant taste in my mouth (yeah yeah, that's what she said. Shut up, baka hentai). Because this was a manga first, I have no idea if the plot is better than the anime. However, there's a very cliche beach episode, and to me, this is where it suddenly becomes a very generic magical harem anime. 


Thinking back on how the show develops, it does feel like things happen a bit too quickly. Like Inuyasha, modern concepts are introduced to a more medieval fantasy realm. Nothing about our modern world is truly explained, nor do we know if this has a negative impact on how the world would have otherwise developed. It just feels like, "Oh sure, here, have some modern conveniences, I can't tell you where it came from though! I'm just going to accept being an OP genius!"


It's rare that I agree with the ratings and reviews from others, but for once I feel like we're all on the same page. I didn't hate the anime, but it lost its appeal after the beach episode with the Jiggly Puff hammocks. It isn't a bad anime to watch, but because the ecchi-style fan service was very suddenly introduced, it just felt like I started losing the plot I was initially interested in. 


At this point I feel like I'm venting my disappointment, so I'll just shut myself up here, lol.

This review will not be terribly long or complex (just long enough that MAL allows it to be posted).  And will be almost totally SPOILER-FREE. 
I can't in good conscience give this a 1, as that implies there was nothing of value gained from it at all.  There's also no way to justify a 10.
This is very much akin to delivery boy-man from Futurama.  They gave the protagonist too many powers.  There was never even a remote chance he could lose/not do something. 
The whole point of this anime was supposed to be that he had his smartphone (that still somehowworked the same) in another world.  Well, the writers seem to have forgotten that after about episode one.  It instead becomes a story focused on the most over-powered protagonist known to man.  Lost your keys?  He has a spell for that.  Need Sherlock Holmes?  He has a spell for that.  Need to destroy a planet?  I can easily surmise he has a spell for that as well.  Want to get the girl?  He doesn't have a spell for that... but apparently he doesn't need it, since every girl in existence is drawn to him anyway.  Honestly... I'd feel a bit better about it if he WAS a pervert who used a spell to get the girl.  Would at least add a potentially funny bit of personality to his character.\n\n
Despite the show's title there is one thing you won't see  in this anime... and that is using a smartphone (ok technically you do see it for like 10 seconds each episode, and episode 1 they actually had made an effort to fit it in... so you get like... 20 seconds).\n\n
This show really has no points it excels in.  But at the same time, it can still be enjoyable to mindlessly veg-out and watch, as long as you go into each episode knowing there will be zero tension and a new girl will most definitely be added to the harem.

Oh boy. I remember when I first found out that this show existed as I was browsing an anime site for something worth watching when this came up on the sidebar. "In Another World with my Smartphone" appeared as a recommendation, and my first instinct was to disregard it for being nothing more than a shitty clickbait ad. But no, it wasn't. It's real. People put time, money, and effort into making this show; but in hindsight they probably didn't put a whole lot of those things into the production of this anime.
That aside, this anime deserves to be seen by everyone. It deserves tobecome one of the most popular anime out there not because people might get invested in the characters or the plot, but because of how irredeemably shitty it is. A good friend of mine and I have taken to scouring the planet for the worst anime out there to entertain ourselves by laughing at the awfulness of Japanese cartoons, and so far this has been one of the best we've seen. The show is bad, yes, but it's GOOD bad. The "development" of the "characters" and "plot" is executed in such a way that makes every episode filled with enjoyment just because it leaves the viewer thinking "is this really fucking happening right now?" When it comes to terrible anime, this show reigns supreme because it seems to constantly ask itself "how can I make the main character and plot get even dumber than it already is?"\n\n
Really, there isn't much else to say that hasn't already been said by countless others. For the most part, I feel it's necessary to let people know that yes, this anime is indeed horrible, but if you're the odd soul like me who likes laughing at some really poorly-made entertainment with friends every so often, then this is the show for you. I look forward the Smartphone season 2 and all the stupidity that will come along with it, because that will be roughly another 6 hours of enjoyment for me and my friend.

It is pure fantasy for every boy. 
If you are looking for a touching story. It's not for you. 
This anime is for guys how like over power characters and random arcs with plots which are meant to make MC look good. There is no direction for the plot of this anime. Its just a bunch of arcs that deals with adventures of a guy with all good powers.
For the people who like Harem endings, this anime is for you. There is no indecisiveness MC. He is engaged with all the girls in the  end much more to come in light novels.
No matter whatothers say its weird anime for weird people who like light heated fantasies.\n
I'm one of them.

First of all... I think all my expectations were.. I don't know.. maybe I was thinking of KonoSuba, Danmachi, Re:Zero kind of setting and guess what? Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni is actually a combination of all those mentioned. Honestly, I have never felt so right about my expectations of an anime before. I was so surprised about my expectations hitting the mark that I can't even compare to how much optimistic this anime is. Don't get me started on even how overpowered the main character was. If only Subaru was able to put his phone to actual use like the main character ofthis anime, Re:Zero could've gotten a better scenery. So this anime was like KonoSuba deprived of comedy, Danmachi with no Action and Re:Zero with an OP main character. What kept this anime going for me is the Harem genre but I could've had better. So.. I don't know if I should recommend this but give it a try, you might find some drama in it. 


Story 5/10: Too optimistic!! Not even a touch of drama or difficulty for the characters. All enemies are taken cared of within 5 minutes. The most difficult part in this anime is the main hero's density. 


Art 9/10: I have to admit that the art style is nice. I think it's the only factor carrying this anime. 


Character 5/10: A Harem.. Character development? none. 


Enjoyment 7/10: Maybe you'll enjoy an anime with no troubles at all.. An anime where everyone gets along. 


Overall 6/10: If there is a sequel, I hope they would improve the story a lot. The Cliffhanger at the end of this should be settled.

Why should you watch this anime? I'll keep this short to play the devil's advocate.
Most people are giving low scores of this anime, and for the reason most of them say, they are correct. The pace is fast, the MC is a little TOO op without any apparent weaknesses with makes him hard to relate to. The characters aren't exactly very interesting and the over all story is a little dull.
Where this anime shines, however, is in the "harem" tag. Most people dislike harem anime for a few reasons that this anime avoids. If you're concerned about these, please, know that you are in fora surprise and watch the anime.


1) MC is too spineless and doesn't pick any of the girls because he doesn't want to hurt any feelings


2) Girls are too spineless and none of them ever tell MC that they love him.


3) The "main" (most likeable/developed) girl is the one that gets the least attention.


############ The rest will spoil the romance, but not plot. ############


This anime casts off those stereotypes and presents a harem in a realistic way: All of the characters love MC, and they do their best to be honest with him and he does his best to be honest with everyone else. It's a true poly relationship, one that thrives by open communication and trust, and making sure that everyone is on equal footing and no one gets left out. To do this, the show also doesn't show a preference towards any particular girl because he doesn't have a "childhood friend" or anyone like that. All of the girls are new to him, and they all get to know each other together.


I almost missed this gem because of what i typed above. It's nice to see a relationship that isn't immature, and people that actually realize what is at stake when you decide to fall in love with someone. This anime will obviously have another season, but even with the big question mark this first season brings, the relationship between the girls and the MC is truly satisfying.

This show is little more than ego masturbation and it plagiarises pretty heavily from Konosuba and Mahouka Koukou no Rettousei in theme and concept.
The story could be summarised as "what would happen if your fantasy came true and everything went your way".
There was a pretty meta discourse in one of the Matrix movies where Neo meets "The Architect" (TA), wherein TA explains how an attempt to provide a perfect alternate reality to appease the human conscious in order to maintain the body by keeping it engaged was rejected by the psyche because it was so, to a lack of better words, unnatural.
You could be forgiventhen for having your suspension of disbelief fail you thanks to this completely unrelatable protagonist in anything other than the context of obviously pure fantasy.


The story starts off KonoSuba style in which a boy dies before his time, but is offered a reincarnation opportunity in recompense for what was apparently a mistake by God which caused said death.


The impossibly humble 15 year old is then given a reward for his humility in death (despite having achieved nothing) by allowing him to take anything he wants with him (also KonoSuba style). He, as the title of the series suggests, takes his (smart)phone with him. So what he really wanted was more of a tablet than a phone because he mostly uses it for its various "apps", especially since the only person he can phone is God himself who you would think by his very nature would find a phone redundant in light of abilities like telepathy or even omnipotence. He also gets a set of arbitrary enhanced abilities such as improved memory retention and combat based muscle memory that allows him to fight with no training. Just because.


What unfolds later are a series of fortunate events in which money, women and all around general success are achieved with little to no effort. Resulting in what could otherwise have just been a wet dream were it not for the plot device played by God tying it all together. Which really makes "God" just an excuse to cut corners in writing. It was at this point i thought there was the potential for it to take a Log Horizon/No Game No Life approach of applying principles from his world like particle physics to develop technology/magical concepts through (re)innovation. But beyond his personal firearm and a few bicycles it's all very vacuous.


The world is fun, i suppose. If not incredibly superficial. Plus the complete lack of personality (or the eventual erasure of any personality that may have been hinted at) in the characters, beyond their expected tropal archetypes, really only fails to provide stimulation. Stimulation otherwise, one would think, relatively easily procured via making them individuals with their own desires, fears and ambitions (beyond "i wanna do lewd things to the MC, if only he'd let me").


The story is nothing the average nerd couldn't think of day dreaming away for 5 minutes. The characters are disappointingly shallow, even for a harem, the art is acceptable, if not dynamically challenged. The value of this shows entertainment can be concisely appraised on its services because that is literally all it provides. It does what it intended to set out, which is not very much at all beyond grasping at the lowest hanging fruit; appealing to the lowest common denominator.


If you like fantasy RPG, alternate realities and ego trips and have a guilty pleasure often found in harem stories then you may find this a moderate way to pass the time. But you could do far better.

It is not ecchi enough compared to how much time it is just about Main Pimp being dull and hoes being shy.
That is as simple as I can put it.
I feel like half of every episode is irrelevant, because MP is op (so fighting doesn't bring anything new to the table), so it is just about MP and girls... MP wont show affection, and girls won't show affection (strongly enough that he could pick it up) or are ignored (too young). Throughout the series, only 2 things that changes are: scale of girls shyness, introduction of new girls.
btw: was watching it with eng dub ...(on the sound score)

Ok so this is my first review ever... 
(CONTAINS SLIGHT SPOILERS FROM EPISODE 1)
I'm fairly new to anime, and i was pretty damn new the first time i saw it.
I had litterally just watched Girls und Panzer and JUST finished SAO before watching this, and before that, nothing.
the weird thing was, after I had finished binging SAO 1 and 2 before watching this, i got a connection I couldnt remove, and I started to feel like this was some sort of game as well, so it was weird to me to understand reality, but whatever. to the actual review.
_______________________________________________________________________
OK, so, this is not a greatanime, technically speaking it's a TERRIBLE anime, and if you're an experienced weeb who has watched houndreds of episodes of different anime, this is not for you at all. maybe with some exeptions.


I enjoyed this because of the fact that I was new to anime and had nothing much to compare it to, which is a huge bonus. If I had watched  Attack on titan, Fairy Tail, SAO, FMA and MHA before watching this (have still only watched two of the examples),  I would absolutely HATE this anime. So all you who has seen a bunch of BIG and popular anime series and movies, stay away from this one... or not :P


The point is, this is not a serious anime, it's not an anime based on story and dark emotions, it's pretty much a happy-go-lucky comedy-harem anime. And that's why I liked it. Serioustly, i'm a super emotional person, I cried through the final part of SAO 2 because of (SPOILER) 










Yuuki... and I cried when I watched episode 4, 7, 11 and 12 of Death Parade... but this was a super good relief for me. 


After watching SAO 2 break my heart into pieces, I needed something less serious, something solemly focusing on happyness, which is why I gave it a go (that and the fact that I browsed the ongoing shows in crunchyroll and clicked on this because it grabbed my attention with the incredibly silly title, which told me everything i needed to know) 


And, I liked it. from the first episode, when I saw what type of anime this is, with thhe main character being OP and all that. and I liked it. I liked the sillyness and unseriousness.


So if you're new to anime and/or need some unserious and silly anime, you should give this one a go. it had me smiling all the way through, and laughing at some of the stupid stuff because of my weird humor.

I know alot of people actually don't like this anime, but TBH i really loved it, and i know it's maybe dumb of me to give it all 10's but i seriously loved it, maybe cause i really LOVE the Isekai genre and really LOVE the Romance genre and there is alot of that X3

I liked it.
Before I attempt to do some sort of "High Brow" Leather armchair, Fine Tabacco Pipe, Brandy Sniffer by the Fireplace review.

Alright, I know what you're thinking, this anime is awful. The concept is amazing, but the character is in every meaning of the phrase, OP. If they limited his power slightly he would have been more interesting. 
BUT! If you stick with this anime, and you learn to laugh at the ridiculousness instead of agonize how he fixes every problem instantly, it is a fun anime. Its funny to see Touya instantly kill 100 enemies, then heal 100 allies. They hardcore embrace the Harem anime theme fitting him to many wives at once, and its fun to see him get the attention of many cutegirls and dance around it. I definitely would rate this what I call a 'trashy anime', they wasted their chance to have him actually do interesting/clever things with his smartphone, but if you can get past caring about intelligence its "fun".

Well. This is definitely a weak anime, but I can't bring myself to give it a bad rating. It has some sort of a somewhat silly, naive and charming quality to it, despite its numerous failures and shortcomings.
Long story short... it is a story about a completely overpowered protagonist that ends up in an isekai world after having an accident in normal life. The protagonist is a supreme Gary Stu, meaning he is pretty much perfect in every aspect and effortlessly solves any problem thrown at him, meanwhile getting involved with more and more girls. I think his Gary Stu power surpasses even that ofthe main character of Mahouka. As a result, the anime is often dull to watch, because something that could be a huge issue often ends up being effortlessly solved by toya (protagonsit) via convenient application of some power.


Basically, it is like watching someone play a game with god mode on and all cheats enabled. However... supporting, despite being realtively weak/cliched and fairly predictable have some charm to them, and if you treat the anime as some sort of relatively weakly done comedy, it works. Sorta. 


Detailed breakdown below.


Story: 4/10:

Well, the main character is a Gary Stu, meaning he is perfect and pretty much without any flaw. Aside from being awkward when interacting with girls, that is (at least he doesn't have glasses and isn't an otaku). Due to his superior power, there's no real conflict in the anime, because all situations are resolved effortlessly. I only saw a similar story in a Re:Monster manga, but toya is even more powerful. However, due to lack of real conflict or danger, the anime looks like some sort of relativley weak comedy with very tame attempts of fanservice. And I mean it that they're very tame - there's no actual nudity in anime, and in situations where it is implied, things usually cover character up. Basically... it is on the "characters get shy over things like holding hands" level. Lots of awkwardness, blushing, etc. The anime also fails to resolve the main storyline and ends with a promise of a second season.


Art: 5/10:

Fairly standard cookie-cutter art. Nothing special about it. Average through and through. Characters are okay, but there's no unique style there, and no great deal of detail, and no superior animation. It does the job, but that's it.


Sound: 5/10:

Same applies to the sound. Nothing really stands out.


Characters: 4/10:

Characters are predictable and  cliched. Toya is the worst, rarely displaying any real personality (aside of getting awkward when interacting with heroines), due to being "perfect". The heroines, however, have some charm/cuteness to them, but it is not kind  of charm where you like the characters, but rather watching an archetype you know well react in a way you can predict. Basically, if you watched a lot of stuff already, it coudl work. Hopefully that makes sense.


Enjoyement: 5/10

Despite the anime being weak, I did not hate it and did not feel like I wasted time watched it. It isn't great by any means, but there was some sort of appeal of watching something with no real danger in it, with people acting awkward all the time in a "cliched anime teenager" way, blushing, etc. Basically it works if you don't expect it to depict an adventure, and watch it like a silly comedy. Or something.


Overall: 5/10

And because of it, I rate it 5/10. Having said that... I think that this anime doesn't offer much of interesting comment, and it is safe to skip it. You won't lose anything if you don't watch it. It has some value if you watch it to unwind, for small elements of comedy and a bit of silliness, but that's about it. It is not a masterpiece, and if you have some other stuff on your "to watch" list, the best idea would be to watch THAT instead. 


So, this is a material you can safely skip and is not "recommended to watch".

Let's just say that we know Mochizuki Touya is the most OP (overpowered) characters we have seen compared to others like Kirito (SAO) and etc. The reason this anime was so good is because of the rom-com element it contains. The main & support characters are awesome and nothing much to comment about. Also, regarding the sound, arts and enjoyment, it is totally a 10 as there were not many problems.
Despite that, I think that the story should be more of where Mochizuki faces difficulty and we need more CUTE LITTLE CHIBI EMPERORS. A SEASON 2 is a MUST as it's the season that thingsgo UP and DOWN like in a roller coaster.

Basically like Konosuba but if everything went right for the MC.
Its a decent anime if you just want to watch something for the fun of it without taking it serious.
I feel like Isekai Wa Smartphone To Tomo Ni would of gotten a better score if towards the later half of the season wasnt too rushed into pushing it as a harem anime. The beginning of this was good as in it was so dumb it was good and funny but like i said i feel it was pushed waaaayyy too hard to be a harem towards the end and it really derailed from the "story"which sadly doesnt really come in until the half of the season.

Well, now let's go for my review of the anime Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni.
Well, first of all I must say that I discovered the anime through a video that criticized it, so I was prepared to hate it.
Until then ....
Story: 7/10
The story is the weakest point of this anime, because it presents a story that, in many ways, is cliche. But many of the conflicts that occur are very original. It may be difficult to understand, so summarizing: The conflict is original, but the way to get there is not.
Also, the way the character resolves the conflicts is very bland as the authorcould very well create a smarter resolution.


Art: 10/10


I am not a critic of art, but for me, the animation was very well done, (although it would be better taken advantage of with scenes of action and struggle) But despite this, all animation appears in a '' smooth '' way


Sound: 9/10


The opening and ending songs are very good, and the songs that play during the scenes are also good, but they are not remarkable. Either way, the songs adapt to where they are applied.


Character: 10/10


I loved all the anime characters, seriously. Although I hated the ending in which {Spoiler to follow}: (all characters end up marrying the main character), the characters are still well built and have their own motivations.


Enjoyment: 9/10


I had a lot of fun watching this anime, but it sure would have more fun if the conflicts had a better resolution.


Overall 9/10


As I have repeated thousands of times, what is missing in this anime are just cool resolutions, in which the character does not solve everything with a single magic or something. The other characters should also have more function in the fights.

The premise of a character bringing a smartphone into a fantasy world was really interesting to me, but unfortunately this was a bit of a disappointment.
The main character is hugely overpowered. If you don't like characters who never really have to struggle to win then you will not enjoy this anime. In fact, the closest thing to genuine conflict the main character faces is him trying to decide how many wives he should have (hint: it's a lot).
Most of the fights are resolved as quickly as possible, so "the harem" can continue being impressed while they stand on the sidelines and do nothing even thoughthey're all supposed to be capable fighters. A good portion of the fights are ended in an instant with the use of a single spell that was played for a gag in the beginning but just...kept...getting...used. Seriously, the main character has the ability to use any spell in existence, but most of the time he instantly wins most of his fights by making his enemies fall over. There are no spectacular fight scenes or visually stimulating battles, he just makes everyone fall over or uses his phone to instantly paralyse everyone in the area.


It's also worth mentioning that the main character really has no character to speak of. Most of the time he's pretty unflappable, always doing the right thing and all the other characters love him but in reality he's incredibly unlikable. I can barely remember his name off the top of my head, having marathoned the entire first season just yesterday, and I definitely can't remember a single notable thing about his character. He has no interests or hobbies, no motivations or goals, no personality whatsoever.

This goes for most of the other characters as well, although at least some of them get brief, fleeting moments of characterisation over the course of the series.


Another issue is the sheer number and size of the plot holes.There are multiple things that happen in the series that don't really have any explanation as to why they happen, and I found it hard to suspend my disbelief that most of the situations in the show would ever arise naturally. I mean, he setup for the series involves God being so apologetic for accidentally killing someone with lightning that he sends them to a fun new world, gives them amazing magical potential and let's them take any item from their old life with them. What about all the other people who die from natural disasters? Where are they? It feels like an exercise in wish fulfillment, where the author couldn't think of a reason for God to be so generous and just made up the first the thing they could think of.


However, all of this pales in comparison to the biggest issue for me. Which is that, in an anime about a guy who takes his smartphone into another world, the main character hardly ever uses his phone as anything. He pretty much just uses it as a SatNav or a camera.

Actually, that's not fair. I think I remember him playing games a few times.

Still, this was criminal for me. Considering the premise was what attracted me to the show, it was really disappointing that very little thought had been put into ways that a modern phone could be used in a pre-technology world.

Not only this, but when he does use the phone, it's in a completely alien and unrelatable way. Most of the time he uses the phone's maps app to cast spells. Occasionally he takes pictures of stuff or googles things. That's about it. There's never any mention of problems with signal, and the electricity problem is explained away as "don't worry, you have magic for that" (no, really). No mention of any of the other myriad of things that a phone can do that would appear like magic to someone in a technology-less, fantasy world - which seemed like a huge waste for me.


Overall, I was very excited when I heard about this show and very disappointed when I'd actually seen it.

NOTE:  In this review I will be talking about the ANIME, not the manga or the LN. I only have some vague ideas as to how the story unfolds in the other media forms but not enough to be a certified expert on the content of the manga or LN. So my review is based solely upon my experience of watching the anime.
Isekai wa Smarphone is a simple and easygoing fantasy adventure anime. It's not an anime of the year let alone anime of its season contender for me. It has its flaws but even in its flaws I still enjoyed the anime forwhat it is.


The premise of the story itself is your basic guy ends up dying in the real world and is resurrected again in another world, bringing with him only the clothes on his back and his smartphone. Now if people are familiar with the Isekai genre and have watched other series, you know exactly what you're getting into. For this anime, that's basically it. Story revolves around the adventures of our MC wandering about in this new world, making new friends and allies. Nothing too serious, no demon king needing to be defeated, no saving some princess or a kingdom under siege, just your typical dude ends up traveling in the world.


Artwise there isn't much to see her. The animation itself looks uneven at places, with character models appearing uneven at times and assuming rather odd poses, such as the certain weird tilts of the faces and facial expressions seeing too static at times. To me the animation is reminiscent of early 2000s anime. The overall aesthetic of the fantasy world did help me to believe that the MC is living in another world, and to that I'll give the anime and its animators some credit. But the unevenness of some of the animations are a bit jarring and shocks me out of my suspension of disbelief.


The music and sound of the anime is generic at best. Your symphonic melodies when a fight scene happens, to the relaxing tones when the characters are walking around in the towns, to the character themes. Personally I enjoyed the piano theme of a certain character. Other than that the sound does convey the right moods at the right times, but don't expect anything too epic. 


Now onto characters. The MC himself is the fish out of water who with a kind heart and willing to help others when necessary. Apart from that good guy personality that he has, that's just basically the depth of his character. I don't seem him grow to be a braver or stronger character up to the series's end, but his simple good guy persona grew on me as the series went on. The other characters your basic fantasy trope characters, who unfortunately lost more of their personality except for some small bits here and there. 


Out of all the characters I've seen only one character I really liked was the MC's main (the series seems to portray her as thus) love interest. You can see by her subtle motions and movements that she seems to genuinely love our MC. She constantly does her best in conveying her emotions to the main character and the concessions she makes for the sake of her beloved and the people around him made me admire the character that she had. In a show where the characters are cookie cutter bland some form of character in the show is better than none.


Overall I did enjoy this anime. Sure, story isn't as deep as the ocean, artwork is questionable and the characters showed little or no character at all but I enjoyed it for what it is. I found it to be a relaxing experience, of a guy who basically just ends up living a second life in a world filled with magic and monsters. 


Just because an anime isn't as grandiose as some other better well animated series out there doesnt make it any less enjoyable.


If you want a very chill anime involving a protag in another world, then I suggest watching this anime. If you're looking for an anime with a meaningful story and deep characters than this anime isn't for you.


Personally I'd suggest it's worth a watch or two. I enjoyed the Isekai wa Smartphone for what it is, a simple anime of a guy living in another world.

(almost) every half-decent anime has a target audience. If you're bored to death of cliches and prefer a series in which stuff actually happens, then Isekai is not for you.
After watching a few episodes, I thought what many probably would've thought, something along the lines of "didn't I just see the same scene last week?","what big eyes you have o.o", "terrible!","reverse satire of konosuba!","as flat as a 5 year old's chest", etc...
Strangely, this series was the only one from this season that I've finished so far, just from the sheer fact that it's such a relaxing watch.
Halfway through, I threw out all my needs fora decent plot, I lost all care for whether or not it's just a cookiecutter fanservice anime or how one-dimensional the characters are and how it's just plain generic (you wouldn't think it's generic unless you watch a lot of anime anyway :P).\n\n
How easy the show was to pick up kept me coming back each week. There's almost no plot, suspense or conflict and it's just a slice-of-life-ish series set in another world where the mc, Touya, effortlessly beats up baddies and gets the girls. When you think about watching the next episode, you don't expect anything from it, thus you have no room for disappointment!\n
I found myself finishing each episode very relaxed, something I don't get when watching a suspenseful, actionpacked or meaningful series that irks me until the next episode comes out.\n
Something happy & upbeat can be a very nice way to finish off a stressful day\n\n
Isekai just what you think it is, nothing more, nothing less, no surprises. Just enjoy it for what it is - if you can't, why watch in the first place?\n
So as a relaxing series, it's very good! Nothing to think about, yet with enough comedy to keep you barely awake (just how bad it is is funny enough sometimes)\n
As an intelligent series with a meaningful plot, it's absolute trash and terribly executed.\n
Given that, I'll give this a 6/10 (a lot of room for improvement but not bad!)\n

You know when LA thinks of having a smartphone in another world, LA would think it would be easy...but NOT THIS EASY.
To be honest, LA had a lukewarm reception when it comes to Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni., it's a non-conflict, piece of cake adventure with no stakes, harem hijinks we have seen over and over again and characters that are blander than plain bread on a white featureless plate with vanilla on top. Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. does everything in it's power to not try AT ALL and revels in giving us easy non-conflict conflicts for the sake of filling theepisode's quota. Does LA utterly hate this anime or is LA hiding something?...


Well let's start with it's many flaws.


Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni.'s characters are by in large stereotypes of many harem shows we've seen time and again, we have the main protagonist Touya Mochizuki who was reincarnated in another world where God tells him he can bring one item to another world (gee where has LA heard this before *cough* KonoSuba *cough*), he obviously brings his smartphone and his personality is the typical nice guy who's dense as a brick on par with Ichika Orimura. Touya is your wish fulfillment character bar none by the way, from the ability to learn EVERY element of magic in this another world, gathering a sizable harem by the anime's end, owning properties and even getting recognition from Kings of TWO Kingdoms, getting almost everything he wants sometimes unintentionally but he goes with the flow anyways and gathers the aforementioned harem in the process. LA is gonna say what LA has been feeling about Touya's character which is "This is what happens when you give Subaru from ReZero the easy route with no deaths", you want Subaru to NOT be a controversial asshole main protagonist who shakes up the plot well here ya go, have Touya instead!. Now what about the harem?..well we have Yae Kokonoe, the Japanese-eqsue lady who's in love with Touya, Leen a magical fairy who is interested in Touya and his magic, twins, Elize and Linze Silhoueska who first meet Touya and get him acquainted with his new world and are generally the older brutish older sister and the shy demeanored younger sister respectively and finally Yumina Urnea Belfast, a princess and Touya's bride to be as she becomes infatuated with Touya after helping her father/king...she's also 12. So yeah basic harem archetypes through and through and really, the characters are the LEAST of Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. problems.


Next is the "skits" this anime pulls. You'd think that Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. where it focuses on another world would have some attracting features to it...well not really as most of the skits falls flat from pure execution and lack of not trying. For one, there are a couple incidents where Touya creates things from his world which would be interesting for a setting like another world and all, it's the execution that fails in this, as such when Touya makes a bicycle because he wanted to, he makes them, but when Linze and Yumina sees it, they do question what it is, but then forgets it and tries to woo Touya by trying to ride a bike, the lack of execution was that what was suppose to be intrigue from characters from another world looking at new items from Touya's world, the focus becomes not about questioning what Touya is making and what it is, but instead trying to have a harem moment by having the majority of the cast trying to woo Touya over something as mundane as riding a bike, something similar also happens with shogi and a GUN of all things with the same deadpan unfocused reactions but the gun creation only works on the grounds that a medieval world having a gun is anachronistic and weird in general and for comparison, in ReZero LA would mention that something similar but better executed happens which actually involved a phone where Subaru was trading his fliptop phone to get an important item from someone and the trader was wondering what it is and was interested in it and wondered how it worked thus giving MUCH more interesting reactions compared to the incidents in Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni.  Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni.'s skits tend to be on the fanservicey side of things as well, from slime monsters trying to tease up the harem members with Touya looking in glee to blatant beach episodes to the talk and showing of panties out of nowhere...yes a bit of fanservice is acceptable even for LA, but when it is this blatant and this forced on it becomes more eye-rolling than acceptably added into a scene. 


The conflicts in Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. is just soo not trying it's boring to watch, LA does find the notion of having a smartphone in another world to be interesting, however when having the smartphone is pressing the easy button time and time again from killing zombie armies in one fell swoop, killing a dragon in no time flat, to HELL why not tame TWO gods with a simple trick, it wears out it's welcome and gives easy access to the anime just not caring about the stakes at hand, it's rather more worried about the harem members blushing at Touya every chance they get and bicker at each other of them trying to push each other to confess to Touya.


For comparisons LA will even say that an anime that came out at the same time as Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. the "isekai mecha anime" Knight's & Magic main protagonist Ernesti goes through more conflicts that aren't easily resolved (besides mooks), he works HARD to get what he wants which uses the anime's central mecha element to his advantage in showing this and goes through hardships through loving what he does and even then Ernesti's rivals aren't just one hit kills or are easily taken care of before the episode ends in comparison to Touya who takes care of the threat in less than a minute and heck Ernesti's rivals even have a dynamic to him of having a different philosophy but same thinking as Ernesti, for Touya he doesn't even HAVE a rival or villain.


So what about the animation from Production Reed?...well although the character designs are exotic and fantasy based, once again because of Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. just not caring about it's battles and stakes, the animation does as little as possible in terms of fighting. Sure there are some fighting here and there but even then it's limited. Production Reed also has many animation derps at times and even dips in quality for an anime already doing as little as possible and LA will mention this but the transitions that appears alot in this anime (you know the transitions with the golden flairs with animated chibi-fied characters doing an aftermath of a situation in question) though good for halfway eyecatches, Production Reed ABUSES this by trying to use as many transitions from each scene to the next and that causes both spatial and location problems ALOT in this anime. What does LA mean?...well because of the transitions meddling in many scenes it causes a disconnect to what area the characters are in and diverts the scene we were just shown for an even lower quality chibi-version of it not knowing what happened after besides the transitions giving the vaguest clue. It's just sloppy and messes with the spatial area the characters are as LA just cannot remembered that ohh yeah Touya owned a mansion, because the transitions showed so little of it LA had forgotten. Production Reed wanted as little effort to do with this anime and it showed.


Voice acting is something LA will praise in some manner of it only in the form of Maaya Uchida and Marika Kouno as it felt like they did try to muster up what little they could from this anime and did it enough for LA to even recognize them. Maaya Uchida as Elize was LA's favourite character by default (and LA says this because again the entire harem doesn't have much personality besides being infatuated with Touya and some preset personalities) due to her brutish tsundere behaviour and Marika Kouno was good as Yumina as she was the competent one/the Momo Deviluke of the harem in Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. though not Momo's devious side, but nonetheless good to see Marika Kouno again LA just wished it was in a better anime, also was it just LA or did LA find it funny that Sumire Uesaka was voicing the foreign chunnibyou character (Leen) in an anime where Maaya Uchida was voicing an aloof older sister archetype? (LA is referring to Anastasia and Ranko Kanzaki from The iDOLM@STER: Cinderella Girls as they swapped character roles in Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni.)


The finale?.....well what do ya know, Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. actually got pretty good, it took them 11 episodes of almost nothing for them to get here, as although the anime was focused on the dynamic of Touya's harem as in the polygamy deal which Yumina instigated, it however fell flat by the end of it. But sparking the notion of it actually happening even in a harem is nearly unheard of (though To Love Ru Darkness is still did it first and better executed and interesting) thus got LA's interest and waned immediately from Touya's answer...but it got LA's interested. Was it enough for LA to watch through all 11 episodes to get to this point? NOPE.


Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. is by in large a poor man's version of an easy run of ReZero or a less funny KonoSuba with a smartphone, it's definitely not the worst anime LA has seen, definitely not as this anime was just boring and not much else, it hardly cares about it's isekai elements and it's harem elements are typical fair cept the one factor during the finale. Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni. was hard to accept as a "so bad it's good" with no stakes, bland characters, plot that is given to the main protagonist instead of earned, harem hijinks we've seen time and again, low effort animation with decent voice acting here and there and ultimately it was in LA's worst anime of Summer 2017 because it's flaws just overwhelmingly outweighed it's strengths.

When it comes to Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni, I thought it was average and the definition of a very cliche anime. The story starts of like how many isekai stories do and then it becomes a lighthearted journey of Touya and his budding harem across this land. It's very easy for anime like this to be hit or miss and Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni falls more near the "miss" category. I think the main cause for this is that the attempts at comedy mostly end up failing making the show feeling bland at points.
The art and animation are slightly below astandard level. The soundtrack just like the story evokes that feeling that the anime is just very cliche although at the very least the soundtrack does make you feel you're in a fantasy setting.\n
The characters are the same cut and dry stereotypes you'll see in any other harem anime. Not that there's anything necessarily too bad about that, it's just that they don't bring anything that's too interesting to the table as a result.\n
As much as I have talked down the anime at this point, Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni wasn't terrible and it was relatively easy to get through. Also I can commend the show for being one of the few harem anime that established it was going to go with a true harem ending.\n
If someday a second season comes around I won't mind at least trying it out. Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni isn't a show I would really recommend but if you happen to have some free time to kill then this anime could be the fix for that.

This show is generic, guy-placed-into-another-world-who-happens-to-also-be-insanely-OP slock. But...
Story: 3.4/10
...it is strangely captivating. That does not save it from what I am about to dive into but it must be noted that there is a sort of captivating charm that surrounds this show.
Anyways, the show's plot is pretty barebones. Dude “accidentally” gets killed by God. God moves kid to another world with his smartphone and just happens to make him attuned to all the different types of magic in the show. Kid eventually meets 4 other traveling companions (all female of course) and they go on various adventures. That's the main jist of the plot. There aresome other elements that get introduced later on but it would be kind of spoilerly to bring up. I'll list them at the bottom of the review.


The main issue with this show's plot is that it is so unapologetic with how generic it is showing its presentation. This will be brought up in all the other categories but for how it comes into play in the story element, the show just doesn't even attempt to go outside the box. The scene transitions? They are just gifs and/or screenshots with like 3 seconds of dialogue. Character development/interactions? MC does something then one or multiple girl(s) blush and fall in love with him even more. Don't get me started on (point #1 at the bottom of the review). Like come on this is the most pandering show I've seen in quite a long time.


The show just comes off as a “minimum viable product”; yes there is a plot and yes things progress but there was no effort put in to make the show interesting or different than all the other isekai shows. Don't even get me started on the dialogue...


Animation: 4.3/10


Literally the most average animation and art I've seen in an anime. It's just...so plain that it's borderline offensive. Colors are bland, the meaning behind the colors are non-existent (colors can tell you a lot about character personalities, make scenes more interesting, ext), the characters models are uninspiring (so many of the main characters look like they were straight up ripped out of other anime), and the animation is as barebones as possible. In fact there are some moments where it literally looks like a slideshow. 


Sound: 5/10


Meh. I wasn't “wowed” with any of the music in this show. It sounded pretty uninspiring and by-the-books for a fantasy themed show. The miscellaneous sound design was much of the same; just bleh and uninspiring. At least it doesn't have the loud distorted sound effects that are present in Fate/Apocrypha...


Characters: 5/10


The characters are super bland and cookie-cutter. They don't even feel like real characters; maybe it is because the MC is so OP and because of that it ends up robbing the other characters of any sort of spotlight moments. Regardless, the other main characters are essentially cardboard cutouts that can blush. The only thing that I can is a positive about this cast is that because the writing is so bad, they, ironically, are actually funny in a decent amount of scenes. Like actually laughing coming out of my mouth because of how horrid their lines are. 


Regardless, the fact that they are all ok with (point #1 at the bottom of the review) really just makes the show even more uninteresting. 


Overall: 4.4/10


The show is average. It is as bland as bland can be. Because of that, it also means the show isn't bad. If you want to waste some time watching bland tropes unfold in front of you, this is not that bad of a time sink. It's by far better than some of the other offerings from this year (cough cough Eromanga Sensei cough cough) so it has that going for it. Like I mentioned in at the beginning, there is a sort of charm within the series but it's not nearly enough to make up for the show's fault. It might however just keep you hanging around till the end.


Enjoyment: 4/10


Thanks for reading my review! If you liked my writing style, would like to see some other reviews, or just want to talk, please stop by my page!


Sincerely,

Awesome Drummer


Spoilers:


(1) So...by the end of the show the MC gets proposed to by all 4 of his traveling companions. Not only that he is prophesied (by a character that can see the future) to eventually have 9 total wives. This is just pandering to an unfathomable level.

In nutshell, It was quite enjoyable in the mean of relaxing until the last 2 episodes.
Let's list what we have in this anime first. An OP MC, A twin sisters, A samurai girls, a loli, a hundred years old loli.
I enjoy the pace at the start admittedly, OP isekai MC gets the girls, moves to next adventure. They develop it in a pretty fast way without dragging. The MC is OP,  they don't prolong much of the fight just for the sake of it. After each episode, we get to see a new side of something. Even though frankly, there is nothing new tobe awe about, you can feel they also did not intend to introduce you to something 'new', but it is more like they briefly introduce their own world in a fast-pace-yet-relaxing-pace-style. It's the same magic fantasy you see out there, they tell you that without trying to make it more complicated than it should be. Therefore it only takes a short time, and we have the rest of screen time for our adventure.


The adventure we have is also not something impressive but I also don't have problems with it -Sure there are flaws over the cliche encounter style, but it is something that can be forgiven due to how they treat it. It is merely a device to introduce something new 'briefly'. Briefly here is probably the keypoint that erases the cliche problem for me.


You can see all chicks start flocking to our MC, but as what it did is exploring its own world, I didn't feel bad about this development. For one reason, it didn't make the MC deal with their feeling just for the sake of resetting it back to status quo. We see the obvious love for the MC, we see how the girls play their little jealous game for MC attention, it's cliche but somehow still funny, and it never pushes the boundary of confronting the feeling, because, again, it's focusing on exploring its own world and their little game only sneaks in for a short time once in a while- at least for the first 10 episode.


The shows would have been a bit better without the last 2 episodes. It failed and did what it shouldn't have done. The straightforward story with no romance dragging is destroyed in the last 2 episodes. Because that is what it did. It is revolving around making a drama of romance and finally reset it back to status-quo. I thought this anime won't do this cheap reset-development, but alas, they did it, and it turned me off greatly.


While nothing impressive exists in this show, it also isn't bad due to its straightforwardness and focusing on what it is doing.

This show was one of the least popular shows talked about on the Japanese 2chan, in which the thread made for specifically criticizing it was actually more popular. And the Japanese are right, this is the perfect anime to feel good about yourself. Just watch Digibro's "The asterisk war sucks" YouTube series and apply everything you learned there. Talking shit about SAO is overrated; just do it to the even lower hanging fruit. 
Besides that, the Character designs were done by 兎塚エイジ (Usatsuka, Eiji), aka the illustrator of the Familiar of zero series; so they aren't bad. 
Music is decent enough, then again the storymakes everything else seem great in comparison. \n
The story is a cluster of convenience and void of any narrative stakes. The one thing the author did do right was foreshadowing. However, foreshadowing does not excuse extraordinary plot convenience. \n
This show is bad, but do not let that ruin the enjoyment of this show for you. I will not judge you for liking this, but golly does this show give me a hate boner and I will proceed to stroke it.\n
以上です！

Isekai wa Smartphone tomo ni is what happens when anime directors just give up entirely. As Amano Keita from Gamers! said, you can try your best to please everyone and include depth in what you make, or you can just throw a bunch of cliches together and make something that's incredibly fun. This is the latter. There is no merit to its plot, depth of character, and even the main character knows that he is way too OP. His harem doesn't even bother hiding their lack of surprise when something incredible happens. There is no struggle. More than an isekai series, this is slice oflife. \n\n
In all, this is incredibly fun to watch, especially if you have gone through a lot of other animes and you know all the stereotypes that exist in anime. Nothing phenomenal, and I'm surprised it even got funded. But I would say that's sort of its charm. This is not unlike cult-gathering films such as Napoleon Dynamite in how exaggerated the stereotypes are, and much like Napoleon Dynamite, I'm pretty sure this series won't be forgotten anytime soon.

Alright. I haven't written a review on an anime in so long but this one really caught my attention. 
DISCLAIMER- There may be spoilers up ahead, minor or major. So here's a heads's up. You can skip to the bottom to read my overall rating for this series. 
Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni/ In another world with my smartphone 
The whole premise of this series starts with Mochizuki, Touya. He dies right in the beginning of the series (reminds me of KonoSuba) But he was actually not meant to die at the moment. 
So God/Kami spoke to his soul and offered Touya to beresurrected in a fantasy world. Touya accepts this offer. God also offered Touya to bring with him one item when going into this world. 


You guessed it, he brought his phone with him. That, and an overpowered affinity for magic and combat. But hey, that's not unusual anymore. Let's be real. 


Let's go ahead and take this step-by-step, shall we? 


Story and Character- 6

Honestly, it's very similar to KonoSuba. The way the MC's die and are reincarnated into fantasy worlds. The differences are very few in between if we look at it. However, Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni does have a bit serious vibe to it. Not /too/ serious, but it has a healthy mix of seriousness and comedy. 


Some of the things that do transpire, however, do seem to be cliche at times.  The character archetypes present are also the common ones we see. The MC is rather bland, though there are times where he does shine. 


It is rather interesting to see Touya, being an entity from a technological civilization, interact with people are not very advanced as of yet. There are those funny moments where people see ice cream or bicycles for the first time and they are ecstatic about them. So I give this series points for that. 


This series is hardcore going for that harem route. Why? Because apparently, in their world, having multiple partners is A-Okay. That seems to fix the whole "you can only choose one of us" thing that is common in harem anime. Everyone wins in this series. 


But because of that, there won't be any interesting conflicts and character interactions since they'll all end up with the MC anyway. 


Art and Sound- 6

The art style for Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni is not the best, but not bad either. There are some times where the character's eyes are too close to each other, or his/her shoulder is too big than it supposedly is. But aside from that, it is very vibrant and they do have some attention to facial expressions. Good for them. 


The VA's did a nice job for voicing the characters according to their archetypes. The shy one sounded shy. The tsundere sounded like a tsundere. I do not have any complaints here.


I was not very attached to the OP and the ED of this series. It's neither good or bad. It's right in the middle for me. I do have this one gripe about the video, however. There is one sequence where the girls show off their power and stuff during the OP. During Yae's sequence, there was a lack of "oomph" to it. All the other girls looked powerful while Yae just ran at the enemy and.. slapped them? Yeah. That's kinda bs to me. 


Overall Enjoyment- 6.5/10

If you're tired of the whole "transported into a fantasy world" plot, then maybe this series is not for you. But if you do take the time to watch it, it's surprisingly enjoyable despite the many cliche's found in it. Isekai wa Smartphone to Tomo ni is not a total waste of your time, guaranteed.

"Wanpaaannn man without the... budget... or comedy... or character depth (lol)"
This show is pretty bad, but I like it. I feel like it's an experiment in trope density. 
It's odd though, the characters are so 1 dimensional that I get the sense that I have no idea what anybody is thinking in the show. Like... retro videos games (bare with me) the graphics were so basic, that your imagination made up detail that was missing. The characters here tap the same vein for me. This can only do so much of course when there's zero payoff but, hey: Tom never did eat Jerry.
On the upside(?),Main guy just straight uses his powers and fixes everything. I've nicknamed this show "Jesus-kun iPhone" It's a great example of wish fulfillment and how it can refreshing when everything doesn't return to status quo at the end of the episode. The main dude is an innocent griffith in disguise with how fast hes moving up the rungs in his new world. (and nobody in proximity seems to have a problem with it)\n\n
I don't recommend this show to anybody accept maybe the most jaded and cynical aneem addict. They would be the ones I'd guess would hate the show so much they might like it in bass ackwards way.

There are times when you have to ask the ultimate question: Why do I like this?
It follows every cliche and trope that you expect in this type of anime. It's more on the comical side of things, but not to gag anime level. The characters, the story lines, everything is just your basic trope anime.
Yet I find myself enjoying it. I don't know why, these are the things I'm normally 'meh' about. 
I do know one thing, and it's the fact that even though it's a comedy, it's jokes are more subdued than what you would expect from a comedy anime. To me that isa good thing, I'm not really into over the top comedy. I like some, but those are few and far between.


Other than that, I have no clue as to why I find enjoyment in this particular anime. This is the type of anime my sister would love, but I never pegged it to be one I would like.


Is it a good anime. No, it's just average. Will I defend it in any sort of way. Psh, no way. Trash it all you want. Will I re-watch it any time in the distant future............. um, no I don't think so. As I've said comedy anime, even ones I think are really good, aren't my cup of tea. Plus this anime really has nothing to it, an okay watch but that's pretty much it.


All in all.... this is just odd. I can't even think of it as a guilty pleasure like some of my other shows. Why do I enjoy this?!?



EDIT: Okay, I've been wanting to do a follow-up for awhile now, but I only had one episode left at that time so I wanted to wait and finish (just to make sure nothing I said was nullified by the last ep).


So before anything else I have to say ........ the novelty of it has worn thin. As I have stated before, I don't care for the harem/ecchi type anime. There are certain peeves I have that they tend to bring in spades (example- girl's skirt gets blown up by the wind, yet the boy gets called a pervert even though he had no control of what happened). This anime starts heading to that but stops short of it, which is something I am grateful for. But at the same time.... it doesn't stop. Every episode has some sort of ecchi (close to being called a perv) moment, and honestly it's getting tiring.


{It may seem I'm going off topic but it connects} This reminds me of a book I read a long time ago. It gave me the sense that it was a self-publish book, it had a few errors. Not spelling errors, rather the way certain sentences were structured was odd. The first time I noticed was on a sentence that I spent a good amount of time re-reading both it and the paragraph, just to figure out what it was saying. It wasn't bad, just one or two odd sentences, but as I continued these errors became more and more noticeable. It got to the point where I had to stop reading it because it was starting to really get on my nerves.


This anime is the same. The ecchi moments were okay when I started the show, but as it went on..... it was the same thing over and over and over and over, till I almost wish it went completely into my peeves just so I could've dropped it sooner (almost). 


Before anyone asks: the reason I did continue, well there are a few reasons. First- while I did realize that I wasn't enjoying it like at the start, I only noticed it annoyed me after episode 11 (I can be slow for certain things), and when I figured that out it made me ponder the series as a whole. Which made me come to the realization that the story was nothing but fluff, and all the jokes were just the same one-trick-pony.

Second- I was curious about the white-haired, red-eyed boy in the opening. I figured he wouldn't have a big part, seeing that he only appeared in the last episode, but I still was curious enough to stay. [spoiler: he doesn't show up till the very end, after the end credits]


If the impossible happens, and this gets a second series you can bet that I will NOT be seeing it. I am done with this show. Completely through with it.

Over and out!

Konosuba: Made in China
Most characters feel reeeally bland, like they were characterised by a 6 year old. The female characters are pratically the same in terms of personality, the main guy is just... the best way to describe him is "Kirito made in china". The art style is very lazy and poor aswell as the animation especially during action scenes. The plot is extremely bland, like one of those old animes for kids except its made to look like its not really for kids. Theres pretty much no main plot, no goal for the character to do which makes the show even more lacking. Andthe only satisfying thing about the show is how OP the main character is, the only reason to even watch this "thing".

This anime series is bad.  I won't beat around the bush it's down right terrible.  As a whole.  It has some good points.  Mainly the visuals and sound but that doesn't make a series complete.  Vincent van Gogh could paint an actual turd and it's still just a turd and Mozart could have written the music to Friday and it would still be a crappy song.  Anyway, after witnessing 6 episodes so far here's my views...  (spoilers of course)
Story:  1
It's a bland story that has been done better.  Guy dies and is reborn in a magicalworld.  But even how he died is boring.  God accidentally killed him cause he was tossing lightning in a field he thought was empty...  Yup,  that's the origin of the story.  Impressed yet?  Neither was I.


So he dies and is able to take anything he wants.  So he take his smartphone...  and somehow it works in this mysterious world with no issues...  no power, no cell network, etc...  maps work, he's able to view peoples locations on it despite them not having a gps tracking device at all...  it just works however he wants.  "how does he keep it powered?" you might be asking...  he learns magic that can charge it...  and speaking of magic.


So in this world people can learn magic.  There are elemental magic like fire and lightning but also something called null magic.  Which is magic developed by single people pretty much over a lifetime which only the people you created it are able to use.  Well guess what?  MC can use ALL the magic.   ALL OF IT.  Making him basically a god in this world which leads him to have no real obstacles in this new world as of yet.  Guy even took down a dragon and was able to summon a god level animal companion on his first attempt...


Art:  8

The art is well done.  It's bright and colourful and the character designs, though lazy, are well done.  No real complaints here.


Sound: 8

Like the art it's well done.  Voice actors are on par, music and sounds effects work.  These two fields are where the show shines.


Character:  2

They may be drawn well but good god are they bland and one dimensional.  MC is OP and clueless to the people around him.  The female characters have all fallen in love with the MC and pine over him.  It's just bleh all over.


Enjoyment:  10

This is the twist to my review.  I am honestly enjoying it.  Not because it's good but because of how bad it is.  It's so bad I can't look away.  I want to see how they can top how OP the MC is in the next episode.  Like I mentioned earlier one episode has him summoning an animal companion with yet another magic he learned and he summons a god level creature on his first time.  "Oh my god this is ridiculous there is no way this can get any worse."  Cut to the next episode where the MC takes down a black dragon.  "well, I thought it couldn't get more ridiculous but here we are again."  


This show is a train wreck.  But it's a train wreck that was full of fireworks so you definitely don't want to look away despite the carnage surrounding it.


Overall: 5

Just the average score of the different categories.  Like I said,  this anime is bad.  It's terrible but it's so terrible it's enjoyable to watch for that fact alone.
